column1: The Catholic Church in Indonesia (Indonesian: Gereja Katolik di Indonesia) is part of the worldwide Catholic Church
column2: under the spiritual leadership of the pope in Rome. Catholicism is one of the six approved religions in Indonesia
column3: the others being Islam
column7: and Confucianism. According to official figures
column8: Catholics made up 2.9% percent of the population in 2010. The number of the Catholics is therefore nearly 7.5 million. Indonesia is primarily Muslim
column9: but Catholicism is the dominant faith in certain areas of the country.

column1: The Church is organised into 10 archdioceses and 27 dioceses
column2: all of which are members of the Indonesian Catholic Bishops Conference (KWI) led by Archbishop Ignatius Cardinal Suharyo Hardjoatmodjo. There are several Catholic religious institutes active in the country including the Jesuits
column3: the Missionaries of the Sacred Heart (MSC) and the Divine Word Missionaries.

column1: Catholicism in Indonesia began with the arrival of the Portuguese in search of the Spice Islands in the 16th century. Currently
column2: East Nusa Tenggara is the only province in Indonesia where Catholicism is the majority
column3: around 55% of its population. There is also a significant Catholic population in North Sumatra

column1: == History ==
=== Brief History ===
In the 14th century
column2: the first Catholic mission that reached Indonesia was led by Italian Franciscan friar Mattiussi. In his book "Travels of Friar Odoric of Pordenone"
column3: he visited several places in today's Indonesia: Sumatra
column6: between 1318–1330. He was sent by the Pope to launch a mission into the Asian interiors. In 1318 he departed from Padua
column7: crossed the Black Sea into Persia and then to Calcutta
column9: and Sri Lanka. Thence he headed to Nicobar island and Sumatra
column10: before visiting Java and Banjarmasin. He returned to Italy by land through Vietnam
column12: and the silkroad to Europe in 1330. The Javanese kingdom mentioned in his record was the Hindu-Buddhist Majapahit kingdom. This mission was a pioneer one
column13: providing the church with some information about Asia. At that time the Catholic church was not yet established in the region
column14: with Hinduism and Buddhism being the religions of the majority of the population.

column1: In the 16th century
column2: the Portuguese sailed east to Asia and eventually captured Malacca in 1511. They came for the spice but Catholic missionaries soon arrived in the region
column3: most notably Francis Xavier who worked in Ambon
column4: Ternate and Morotai (Halmahera) in 1546–1547. Dominican missionaries also converted many in Solor. With the expulsion of Portugal from Ternate in 1574
column5: many Catholics in the northern Moluccas were killed or converted to Islam. Ambon was conquered and occupied by the Dutch East India Company in 1605. Subsequently
column6: the Catholics were forced to convert to Protestantism. The same happened in Manado and the islands of Sangihe-Talaud. In 1613 Solor also fell to the Dutch
column7: and Catholic mission activities declined in Flores and Timor
column8: even though these were still under Portuguese administration.It was not until 1808 under H.W. Daendels
column10: that Catholics were permitted freedom of worship in the Dutch Indies
column11: though this measure was mainly intended for European Catholics since Daendels ruled under the authority of Napoleonic France. This freedom was consolidated by Thomas Raffles.

column1: From 1835 the Catholic Church was affiliated with the colonial state: clergy received a salary from the colonial government which in turn had the right to reject church appointments. In 1846
column2: clashes over policy led the Dutch authorities to expel all but one of the Catholic priests in the colony. In 1848 there were Catholic churches in only four centres in the colony.Active mission work resumed in the second half of the 19th century and was concentrated in a few areas. Larantuka in the island of Flores was a particularly important mission field under the Jesuits because the freedom of the Catholic Church was guaranteed there under an 1859 treaty with Portugal
column3: which settled conflicting territorial claims in the region. Bengkulu
column6: and the islands south of New Guinea were also important. In other regions
column7: Catholic mission work was banned. Many Batak people in the interior of North Sumatra adopted Catholicism at this time
column8: even though authorities banned Catholic missionaries in other parts of the province. In 1898
column9: a mission program also began in Muntilan
column10: though the first ethnic Javanese priest was not installed until 1926.After Indonesian independence
column11: the Church grew steadily although the Dutch and other Europeans were expelled. Catholicism and other religions grew phenomenally after the Overthrow of Sukarno in 1965.

column1: === The Portuguese Era ===
Portuguese explorers arrived in the Maluku Islands in 1534
column2: with the goal of converting the natives to Catholicism and to obtain valuable spices endemic to the region. The Spaniard Francis Xavier
column3: a co-founder of the Jesuit Order
column4: worked in the islands from 1546 to 1547 and baptised several thousand locals of the islands of Ambon
column6: laying the foundations for a permanent mission there. Following his departure from Maluku
column7: others carried on his work and by the 1560s there were 10
column9: mostly on Ambon; by the 1590s there were 50
column11: 000. Portuguese Dominican priests also had some success in missionary activities on Solor whereby the 1590s the Portuguese and local Catholic population is thought to have numbered 25

column1: === The VOC Era ===
Cornelis de Houtman was the first Dutchman who sailed east to modern-day Indonesia
column2: in 1595. Although his expedition could be considered a commercial failure
column3: it showed the Dutch they were able to sail east in search of the spices. In 1602 the Dutch East India Company (VOC) was created. The Netherlands
column5: had a staunchly Protestant government at the time
column6: which extended to the VOC; even though there were many Dutch Catholics
column7: they had little influence. Ambon was conquered and occupied by the VOC in 1605
column8: and the Catholics were forced to convert to Protestantism. The same happened in Manado and the islands of Sangihe-Talaud. In 1613 Solor also fell to the Dutch
column9: and Catholic mission activity was reduced in Flores and Timor
column10: which were still under Portuguese administration.The Catholic priests were replaced with Protestant clergy from the Netherlands.  Many Christians at the time converted to Protestantism.  For some time
column11: Catholic priests were threatened with capital punishment if found to be residing in VOC territory.  In 1624
column12: Father Egidius d'Abreu SJ was executed in Batavia during the administration of Governor-General Jan Pieterszoon Coen

column1: Father Alexander de Rhodes
column2: a French Jesuit who invented the Vietnamese westernized alphabet system
column3: was forced to watch his cross and Mass accessories burned underneath where two convicted thieves were just hung to their deaths.  De Rhodes was then expelled from VOC territories in 1646.John Gaspard Cratz
column5: was forced to leave Batavia due to difficulties with the administrators when he helped Catholic priests who were in transit in Batavia. He was moved to Macau
column7: and died as a martyr in Vietnam in 1737.At the end of the 18th century Western Europe saw intense warfare between France and Great Britain and their respective allies.  The sympathies of the people of the Netherlands were divided
column8: and the Netherlands lost its independence.  In 1799 the VOC went bankrupt and was dissolved.  In 1806 Napoleon assigned his brother Louis Bonaparte
column10: to the throne of the Netherlands.

column1: === The East Indies Era ===
The change of politics in the Netherlands
column2: mainly because of the accession of Louis Bonaparte
column3: a fervent Catholic
column4: brought a positive effect. Religious freedom was recognised by the government. On 8 May 1807
column5: the pope in Rome was given permission from King Louis to establish an Apostolic Prefecture of East Indies in Batavia.

column1: On 4 April 1808
column2: two Dutch priests arrived in Batavia. They were Fr. Jacobus Nelissen and Fr. Lambertus Prinsen. Nelissen became the first Apostolic Prefect when the Apostolic Prefecture of Batavia was created in 1826.

column1: Governor-General Daendels (1808–1811) replaced VOC with the government of Dutch East Indies. Religious freedom was then practised
column2: although Catholicism was still difficult.

column1: === The Van Lith Era ===
Catholicism started to spread in Central Java when Fr. Frans van Lith from the Netherlands came to Muntilan
column2: Central Java
column3: in 1896. His effort showed little progress until 1904 when four chiefs (the heads of the town) from Kalibawang region came to his house and demanded that he catechize them.  On 15 December 1904
column4: a group of 178 Javanese were baptised at Semagung
column5: between two trees called "Sono". This place is now called Sendangsono in Muntilan
column8: near the border of the province of DI Yogyakarta.

column1: Van Lith also established a school for teachers in Muntilan called "Normaalschool" in 1900 and "Kweekschool (also for teachers)" in 1904. In 1918
column2: all Catholic schools were put under the jurisdiction of an institute named "Yayasan Kanisius"
column3: which produced the first priests and bishops of Indonesia. In the 20th century

column2: Van Lith established the "Seminari Menengah" (minor seminary). Three out of the six candidates that were at the school during 1911-1914 were received into the priesthood in 1926-1928. Those priests were FX Satiman SJ
column3: Adrianus Djajasepoetra SJ

column1: === World War II and the War of Independence ===
Albertus Soegijapranata SJ became the first Indonesian bishop in 1940 and later Archbishop of Semarang.
On 20 December 1948
column2: Father Sandjaja and Brother Hermanus Bouwens SJ were killed in a village called Kembaran
column3: near Muntilan
column4: when Dutch soldiers attacked Semarang. Father Sandjaja is recognised as a martyr by the Indonesian Catholics
column5: (not officially canonized or approved by the Holy See).

column1: Monsignor Soegijapranata with Bishop Willekens SJ faced Japanese colonial rule. They managed
column2: however
column3: to keep Saint Carolus Hospital operating normally.

column1: Some of the most notable Indonesian national heroes are Catholics
column2: including Agustinus Adisoetjipto (1947) after whom is named Yogyakarta International Airport
column3: Adisutjipto Airport

column1: === The Post-Independence Era ===
The first Indonesian archbishop to be made cardinal was Justinus Darmojuwono on 29 June 1967. Indonesian Bishops took part in the second Vatican Council
column2: which was convened from 1962 to 1965.

column1: Pope Paul VI visited Indonesia in 1970
column2: followed in 1989 by Pope John Paul II. The places visited were Jakarta (capital of Indonesia)
column3: Medan (North Sumatra)
column7: and Dili (Timor Timur) (now the country of East Timor).

column1: The head Archdiocese of Jakarta ("Keuskupan Agung Jakarta")
column2: is Archbishop Ignatius Suharyo Hardjoatmodjo. Indonesia's only cardinal is Julius Darmaatmadja SJ. He took part in the conclave which elected Pope Benedict XVI. For health reasons
column3: however
column4: he declined to take part in the recent conclave that elected Pope Francis.

column2: after the overthrow of Sukarno
column3: a purge was carried out against Indonesian communists and alleged communists
column4: especially in Java and Bali. Hundreds of thousands
column6: of civilians were killed in the ensuing turmoil by the army and vigilantes. Communism was associated with atheism and since that time every Indonesian citizen has been expected to adopt one of the then five official state-endorsed religions.Catholicism and other minority religions have experienced enormous growth especially in areas inhabited by large numbers of Chinese Indonesians and ethnic Javanese. For example
column7: in 2000 in Jakarta alone there were 301
column10: 955. This means the Catholic population increased elevenfold while in the same period the population of Jakarta merely tripled
column15: 000. This growth may also be attributed to increased migration to the capital from Christian parts of Indonesia when in 1960 there were not so many from the regions residing in Jakarta as now.

column1: The dramatic increase of the number of Catholics in particular
column2: and Christians in general
column3: has led to enmity and unfounded allegations of "Christianization".The second half of the 1990s and beginning of the 2000s were also marked by violence against Catholics in particular and Christians in general. However
column5: himself a leader of Nahdatul Ulama
column6: one of the biggest Muslim organisations in Indonesia
column7: made several contributions in reconciling the simmering antipathy among the different religious groups.

column1: As recently as 2010
column2: there were incidents where Catholics and other Christians were banned from celebrating Christmas services.

column1: == Demographics ==
The Indonesian Central Statistic Bureau (BPS) conducts a census every 10 years. Data available from 2000 drew on 201
column3: 999 survey responses. BPS estimated that the census missed 4.6 million people. The BPS report indicated that 85.1 per cent of the population label themselves Muslim
column9:
including traditional indigenous religions, other Christian groups, and Judaism. The country's religious composition remains a politically charged issue; as some Christians, Hindus, and members of other minority faiths argue that the census undercounted non-Muslims.
